respStmt.name: Kathryn Starkey, Mae Lyons-Penner, Marieke Reisch, Robert Forke, Chris Hutchinson, Patrick ???, Björn ???

publicationStmt.publisher: TO BE DECIDED! SOMETHING ABOUT STANFORD

lem.p: Planctum istum facit beata virgo Maria cum quattor personis deuotis deuotissime bona sexta feria ante prandium in ecclesia ante chorum in loco aliquantaum eleuato vel extra ecclesiam, si bona est aura.

rdg.p:
Here begins the most devout lamentation of the Blessed Virgin Mary in a compassionate and devout exposition.
Here, the Latin “nota” is not easy to translate. Alternatively, it could be understood to mean “depiction” or “style”.
This lamentation is performed faithfully and very devoutly by the Blessed Virgin Mary together with four other characters before lunch on Good Friday, in the church in front of the choir or, if the
In medieval monastic contexts, the “prandium” was, according to the Benedictine Rule, the principal meal of the day which the whole community gathered for around noon.
light is good, in a moderately raised place outside of the church.

lem.p: Planctus iste non est ludus nec ludibrium, sed est planctus et fletus et pia compassio Marie virginis gloriose.

rdg.p: This lamentation is neither a play nor a funny joke, but is a lamenting and a wailing and devout compassion for the glorious Virgin Mary.

lem.p: Et cuandocunque fit a bonis et deuotis hominibus, in genere siue in specie valde prouocat homines circumstantes ad pium fletum et ad compassionem.

rdg.p:
And in general or in particular, whenever it is performed by good and devout people it will
The Latin expression “in genere sive in specie” is a formulaic idiom. Here, it expresses that the described qualities and effects of the play do not only apply to this particular Middle Low German version, but to the genre of Marian lamentations in general.
strongly provoke the gathered people to piously cry and feel compassion,

lem.p: sicut facit sermo deuotus bona sexta feria de passione domini nostri Jhesu Cristi.

rdg.p: just as a devout Good Friday sermon on the passion of our Lord Jesus Christ does.

lem.p: Si non potest fieri bona sexta feria commodose propter sermonem de passione domini, tunc beata virgo faciat istum planctum antea cum suis, sicut feria secunda post dominicam palmarum ante prandium.

rdg.p: If, because of the sermon on the Lord’s passion, it is not possible to perform on Good Friday, at the time when the Blessed Virgin together with her confidantes once broke out into this lamentation, [it shall be performed] on the Monday of the Holy Week before lunch

lem.p: Iste planctus fit commodose in duabus horis et media.

rdg.p: This lamentation can be conveniently performed in two and a half hours.

lem.p: Et omnia, que tunc fiunt ab illis quinque personis, non debent fieri cum festinacione nec nimia mora, sed medio et bono modo.

rdg.p: And everything which was once done by these five persons shall not be performed in a hurry or exaggeratedly slow, but medium-fast and in a good way.

lem.p: Ille, qui est Jhesus, est deuotus sacerdos.

rdg.p: The actor playing Jesus is a devout priest.

lem.p: Maria iuuenis.

rdg.p: Mary is a young man.

lem.p: Johannes ewangelista sacerdos.

rdg.p: John the Evangelist is a priest.

lem.p: Maria Magdalena et mater Johannes ewangelista iuuenis.

rdg.p: Mary Magdalene and the mother of John are young men.

lem.p: Jhesus debet se preparare cum casula rubra.

rdg.p: Jesus must wear a red vestment.

lem.p: Johannes simili modo.

rdg.p: John must do the same.

lem.p: Jhesus et Johannes debent habere dyademata de papiro; dyadema Jhesu habeat rubram crucem ante et retro.

rdg.p: Jesus and John are wearing crowns made of paper; Jesus’ crown shows a red cross at the front and the back.

lem.p: Maria debet se preparare cum vestibus, sicut Maria Magdalena in nocte pasche.

rdg.p: Mary must wear a garment like that of Mary Magdalene for the Easter vigil.

lem.p: Johannes habeat gladium de ligno cum vagina, quem tenet in manu, quum exit cum rigmo suo.

rdg.p:
John has a wooden sword with a sheath which he holds in his hand and with
This reference points to a non-extant Easter play that the Augustinian monks of Bordesholm seem to have performed regularly. It shows how late medieval liturgical drama was far from being a singular event and in fact was deeply embedded into the rhythm of monastic life.
during his rhymed monologue.

lem.p: Et Johannes debet sepius tangere cor Marie vel pectus eius.

rdg.p:
And John has to touch Mary’s heart or
Latin “rigmus" is a technical term in medieval drama, denoting a rhymed and spoken (not sung) monologue.
chest seven times. And when he has performed his part, he immediately lays down the sword.
Gramatically, the Latin „sepius“ makes no sense here. We assume that it is a scribal mistake or an abbreviation for „septimus“, referring to the seven sorrows of the Virgin Mary.

lem.p: Et quum facit actum suum, statim deponit gladium.

rdg.p: And when he has performed his part, he immediately lays down the sword.

lem.p: Iuuenis quidam bene vestitus potest postea lumbos crucifixi.

rdg.p: Well-costumed young men may take away the sword together with the cloth of silk with which the Blessed Virgin before had covered the loins of the Crucified.

lem.p: Dominus Jhesus cum primo exit cum alijs quattuor personis, deuote portat crucem in manibus suis.

rdg.p: In the beginning, the Lord Jesus enters the stage with the four other characters, devoutly carrying the cross in his hands.

lem.p: Et quum cantauit versum "Quoniam tribulacio proxima est", statim deponit crucem.

rdg.p: And when he has sung the verse “For tribulation is near,” he immediately lays down the cross.

lem.p: Et quum faciunt planctum, dominus Jhesus debet habere crucifixum ante se.

rdg.p: And when they perform the lamentation, the Lord Jesus must hold the cross in front of him.

lem.p: Et cuandocunque facit actum, tunc crucem deponit et intrudit crucifixum.

rdg.p: And as soon as he has performed this act, he puts down the cross and rams the crucifix into the ground.

lem.p: Beata virgo stat a dextris Jhesu Cristi cum Maria Magdalena.

rdg.p: Together with Mary Magdalene, the Blessed Virgin stands on the right side of Jesus.

lem.p: Johannes a sinistris cum matre sua.

rdg.p: John and his mother stand on the left.

lem.p: Virgo Maria quum facit actum suum, vadit ad medium et aliquando vertit se ad filium ad orientum, aliquando ad occidentem, aliquando ad aquilones, aliquando ad meridiem cum gladio Symeonis, quem tenet beatus Johannes ante pectus eius.

rdg.p: When the Virgin Mary performs her part, she steps into the center and at one point turns east towards her son, at one point to the west, at another point to the north, and at one point to the south and towards the sword of Simeon, which St. John holds to her chest.

lem.p: Aliquando beata virgo expandit brachia sua, aliquando leuat manus suas ad filium cum oculis: omnia cum moderamine.

rdg.p:
At one point, the Blessed Virgin reaches out her arms,
Medieval churches are generally oriented to the east: Therefore, the altar, cross and choir are behind Mary (east), the nave with the audience is in front of her (west), John the Evangelist stands to her left (south) and north means right of her.
at another point she raises her hands and eyes to her son: all with moderation.

lem.p: Quandocunque fecit actum suum, vadit at locum suum et stat a dextris.

rdg.p: As soon as she has performed her part, she steps back to her place and stands on the right.

lem.p: Simili modo faciunt alij.

rdg.p: The others do the same.

lem.p: Quum exeunt et quum intrant, faciunt tria paria: primo exit dominus Jhesus cum cruce cum Johanne ewangelista, post hos beata virgo cum Maria Magdalena, vltimo mater Johannes cum rectore, et ille incipit psalmum "Circumdederunt me viri mendaces" vsque ad locum preparatum.

rdg.p:
When they enter and exit the stage, they make up three pairs: first of all, the Lord Jesus
Here, the use of Latin words is counterintuitive to English speakers: „exire“ means entering, „intrare“ exiting the stage.
enters with the cross and John the Evangelist, after them the Blessed Virgin and Mary Magdalene, finally the mother of John with the rector, who strikes up the psalm “Lying men surrounded me”
The rector is the priest who leads the liturgical singing and recitations that take place during the play.
until [he reaches] a prepared place.

lem.p: Ffinito psalmo dominus Jhesus cantat solus versum "Quoniam tribulacio proxima est" et vertit faciem ad occidentem semper.

rdg.p: After the end of the psalm, Jesus alone sings the verse “For tribulation is near,” turns his face westwards and stays this way.

lem.p: Vnusquisque dicat rigmum suum cum deuocione plangendo in eadem et nota et dono discreto.

rdg.p:
Everyone recites his rhymed
Jesus is facing the audience.
monologue mourning with devotion, in the same character and in a discreet tone of voice.
Here, the sonorization typical for Middle Low German is reflected in the Latin spelling of the manuscript: „dono“ does not derive from „donum“ (meaning „gift“), but from „tonus“ (meaning „tone of voice,“ „note,“ „inflection“).

lem.p: Quum Jhesus finiuit versum "Quoniam tribulacio", Johannes ewangelista statim dicit ad omnem populum plangendo:

rdg.p: When Jesus has finished the verse “For tribulation is near,” John the Evangelist immediately turns to all the people and sorrowfully says:

lem.speaker: Johannes ewangelista

rdg.speaker: John the Evangelist:

lem.l: Horet, gij salighen lude,

rdg.l: Listen, you blessed people,

lem.l: Vnde latet juw beduden,

rdg.l: and let it be shown to you

lem.l: Wo vnse leue here Jhesu Crist,

rdg.l: how our dear Lord Jesus Christ,

lem.l: De eyn schepper hemmels vnde eerden ist,

rdg.l: Creator of Heaven and Earth,

lem.l: Huden vmme vnsen wyllen heft geleden de marter grot,

rdg.l: today suffered great torture for our sake,

lem.l: Dar tho ok den bytteren dot!

rdg.l: and, in addition to that, bitter death!

lem.l: Horet ersten, wo vnse leue here an der tijt to completen

rdg.l: Hear, first of all, how our dear Lord at the time of Compline

lem.l: Vmme vnsen wyllen blodich sweet wolde sweten;

rdg.l: sweated bloody sweat for our sake,

lem.l: Dat he alwyllynges ok wolde ga&esup;n,

rdg.l: and how he also went voluntarily

lem.l: Dar en syne vygende wolden va&esup;n;

rdg.l: to where his enemies caught him,

lem.l: Dat he Judam, synen valschen vrund,

rdg.l: and how he kissed Judas, his disloyal friend,

lem.l: Kussen wolde vor syne munt

rdg.l: on the mouth,

lem.l: Vnde valsklyken wolde vorraden werden,

rdg.l: when he was about to be betrayed as treacherously

lem.l: Alse gy eyn mynsche vp dusser erden.

rdg.l: as any man who ever walked the earth.

lem.l: De yoden, de he hadde van herten leeff,

rdg.l: The Jews, whom he loved with all his heart,

lem.l: Venghen ene alse eynen morder vnde deeff.

rdg.l: took him captive as if he were a murderer or a thief.

lem.l: He wart ok in den suluen stunden

rdg.l: In the same hour,

lem.l: Vor Annas ghetoghen vnde gebunden;

rdg.l: he was also dragged before Annas and bound;

lem.l: De beghunde en vmme syne lere tho vragen.

rdg.l: he [Annas] began to question him about his teachings

lem.l: Do wart he in syne hilgen wanghen geslagen.

rdg.l: There he was struck on his holy cheeks.

lem.l: Horet, wo vnse leue here in der nachtstunde

rdg.l: Hear how our dear Lord on that night

lem.l: Vmme vnsen wyllen wart gevangen vnde gebunden

rdg.l: was taken captive and bound for our sake

lem.l: Vnde wort vor byschop Cayphas getoghen!

rdg.l: and was dragged before bishop Cayphas!

lem.l: Dar wart he so rechte ouele beloghen:

rdg.l: There he truly was basely slandered:

lem.l: Syne vygende, de yoden, dar to rade gynghen,

rdg.l: his enemies, the Jews, took counsel

lem.l: Wo se ene mochten to deme dode bryngen.

rdg.l: there about how they might put him to death.

lem.l: Dar horde vnse leue here mennich smelyk word:

rdg.l: There our dear Lord heard many scornful words:

lem.l: Se staffeden syne werden hylgen bord,

rdg.l: they insulted his worthy, holy birth,

lem.l: Se seden, dat he nicht were godes kynd,

rdg.l: they said that he wasn’t the son of God;

lem.l: Also deger weren se vorblynd.

rdg.l: that is how very blind they were.

lem.l: Syne gotlyken ogen see vorbunden;

rdg.l: They bound his godly eyes;

lem.l: Alumme en de grymmighen yoden stunden

rdg.l: all around him stood the grim Jews

lem.l: Vnde hadden en vor enen doren

rdg.l: who took him for a fool

lem.l: Vnde slogen en to synen gotlyken oren.

rdg.l: and struck him around his godly ears.

lem.l: Se spreken smelyken: bystu Crist,

rdg.l: They spoke mockingly: if you are Christ

lem.l: So entrade, van weme du geslagen byst!

rdg.l:
then tell us who hit you!
The literal meaning of “entrade” is “guess correctly”.

lem.l: Se bespygeden syn gotlyke antlat,

rdg.l: They spat on his godly countenance,

lem.l: Se makeden dat vul vnreyne vnde nat, -

rdg.l: they sullied and drenched it completely –

lem.l: O leuen vrundes, wat groter smaheyt was em dat!

rdg.l: O dear friends, what a terrible offence this was to him!

lem.l: Horet, wo vnse leue here wart vor Pylatum gebracht!

rdg.l: Hear, how our dear Lord was brought before Pilot!

lem.l: Dar wart he so rechte ouele bedacht:

rdg.l: There he was truly mistreated:

lem.l: Se seden, dat vnse here were eyn droghenere

rdg.l: they said that our Lord was a deceiver

lem.l: Vnde lerede deme volke ok valsche lere.

rdg.l: and also that he taught the people false teachings.

lem.l: Pylatus sende vnsen heren hen to herodes;

rdg.l: Pilot sent our Lord to Herod

lem.l: De wart sere gevrowet des:

rdg.l: who was very pleased about this:

lem.l: He me&esup;nde, dat he were eyn to&esup;uerer

rdg.l: he thought that he [our Lord] was a conjurer

lem.l: Vnde ok der lude gokeler.

rdg.l: and also a misleader of the people.

lem.l: Herodes hadde gerne wunder van em geseen;

rdg.l: Herod would have gladly seen some of his miracles;

lem.l: Des enmochte em doch nicht bescheen.

rdg.l: but that was not to happen for him.

lem.l: He began vnsen heren vele to vraghen,

rdg.l: He began to ask our Lord many questions

lem.l: Vnde de yoden begunden ouer em sere to klaghen:

rdg.l: and the Jews began to complain greatly about him;

lem.l: Vnse here sweech al stylle vnde wolde em nicht berichten,

rdg.l: and our Lord kept completely silent and would not tell him anything;

lem.l: Do bespottede Herodes Jhesum Cristum myt alle synen knechten,

rdg.l: then Herod, with all his men, mocked Jesus Christ.

lem.l: He to&esup;ch em eyn do&esup;ren kleyt an

rdg.l: He dressed him in a fool’s costume

lem.l: Vnde let en also wedder to Pylatum gan.

rdg.l: and sent him back to Pilot like that.

lem.l: Dat le&esup;et vnse leue here myt groder dult

rdg.l: Our dear Lord endured this with great patience

lem.l: Vor vnse sundychlyken schult.

rdg.l: for our guilty sins.

lem.l: Horet, wo vnse leue here vmme vnse sunde

rdg.l: Hear, how our beloved Lord was pitifully bound

lem.l: Yamerliken vmme eyne zule wart gebunden!

rdg.l: to a column for the sake of our sins!

lem.l: Also mortlyken sere

rdg.l: Thus was our dear,

lem.l: Wart do geslagen vnse werde truten here,

rdg.l: worthy Lord murderously beaten.

lem.l: Lat an al synem lychamme nicht heles enbleeff

rdg.l: No part of his body was left intact

lem.l: Vnde syn dure blo&esup;d ouer alle syn leuent dreff.

rdg.l: and his precious blood ran all over his living body.

lem.l: Se vlechteden eyne scharpe do&esup;rne krone;

rdg.l: They wove a sharp crown of thorns

lem.l: De druckeden se an syn houet schone,

rdg.l: and pressed it down upon his fair head

lem.l: Dat syn hylge dure blo&esup;t

rdg.l: so that his holy, precious blood

lem.l: Ouer syn hilge antlat vlo&esup;t.

rdg.l: flowed down over his blessed countenance.

lem.l: Dar worpen se vort ere vule spekelen an,

rdg.l:
They spat foully [upon him]
Literally: they threw off their foul spit

lem.l: Dat he wart gestalt alse eyn spyttels man.

rdg.l: so that he looked like he was made of spit.

lem.l: Se slogen syn hilge houet myt enem rore

rdg.l: They beat his blessed head with a rod

lem.l: Vnde belacheden Marien kynt alse enen doren;

rdg.l: and laughed at Mary’s child as if he were a fool.

lem.l: Se togen em eyn purpuren kleyt an vnde vyllen vp ere knee

rdg.l: They dressed him in purple and fell to their knees:

lem.l: Ghegrutet systu, der yoden koningh! ho&esup;nlyken spreken see.

rdg.l: “Hail to you, King of the Jews!”, they said disdainfully.

lem.l: Dar negest wart vnse leue here vor gherichte getogen

rdg.l: After that our dear Lord was dragged before the court

lem.l: Vnde menniger hande wijs valschlyken beloghen.

rdg.l: and was treacherously slandered in many different ways.

lem.l: Eyn valsch ordel wart ouer em geda&esup;n,

rdg.l: A false verdict was passed on him so

lem.l: Dat me ene scholde an eyn krutze sla&esup;n.

rdg.l: that they crucified an innocent man.

lem.l: He droch synes sulues crutze vth der stat;

rdg.l: He dragged his cross of beams out of the city.

lem.l: Tho groter smaheyt schach em dat.

rdg.l: It was a great disgrace that this happened to him.

lem.l: Se hangeden en daran lyk enem mysdedegen deue.

rdg.l: They hanged him on it like a scurrilous thief.

lem.l: Do bewysede he vns syne groten leue,

rdg.l: There he showed us his great love

lem.l: In deme dat he vor syne vygende bat,

rdg.l: by praying for his enemies;

lem.l: Dar he af geleden hadde pyne vnde groten hat.

rdg.l: there he had cast off pain and great hatred.

lem.l: He leyt bynnenwendych alto grot herte swere,

rdg.l: His suffering was yet even greater:

lem.l: Do he syne werden moder Marien

rdg.l: inside, he suffered great and unbearable anguish when he heard his worthy mother Mary

lem.l: Horde bytterlyken sere wenen vnde scrygen.

rdg.l: very bitterly weeping and crying.

lem.l: Dar weren ok twe mo&esup;ordere gevangen;

rdg.l: Two murderers had also been caught; disgracefully,

lem.l: Dar wart he smelyken twyschen gehanghen.

rdg.l: he was hung between them.

lem.l: Deme enen vorgaff he in der latesten stunde

rdg.l: He forgave one of them in his final hour

lem.l: Vmme eyne korte ruwe al syne sunde.

rdg.l: after he had done brief penance for all his sins.

lem.l: Vnse leue here rep ok eynen yamerlyken schrey:

rdg.l: Our beloved Lord let out a woeful cry:

lem.l: Hely, hely, lamazabathani!

rdg.l: “Hely, hely, lamazbathani!”

lem.l: Dat ys: myn got, myn got, worvmme hestu my vorgeten?

rdg.l:
That is to say: “my God, my God, why have you forsaken me?”
Matthew 27:46

lem.l: Do bespotteden en de yoden vnde dar entyegen repen:

rdg.l: Then the Jews mocked him and shouted back at him:

lem.l: Kum hijr nedder van deme crutze, bystu Crist,

rdg.l: “Come down here from the cross if you are Christ

lem.l: So wyl wij louen, dattu godes sone byst!

rdg.l: then we will believe that you are God’s son!”

lem.l: Dar negest eschede vnse leue here drynken;

rdg.l: Thereafter our beloved Lord asked for a drink;

lem.l: Do leten se em etyk vnde gallen schenken.

rdg.l: then they had vinegar and gall brought to him.

lem.l: Dar neghest sprak he: consummatum est!

rdg.l:
Thereafter he spoke: “it is finished!"
“consummatum est”, John 19:30

lem.l: Vnde ok: in dyne hende bevole ik, vader, mynen geyst!

rdg.l: And also: “In your hands father, I command my spirit!”

lem.l: Also leyt do den bytteren dot vnse leue here.

rdg.l: Thus our lord suffered bitter death.

lem.l: Ok wart syne hilghe syde doresteken myt enem spere;

rdg.l: Thus his holy side was pierced with a lance;

lem.l: Dar vlo&esup;t vth water vnde blot.

rdg.l: water and blood flowed out of it.

lem.l: Dar sach me do an den creaturen yammer grot:

rdg.l: Then the creatures were seen to suffer great sorrow:

lem.l: De harden steyne toreten van synen pynen,

rdg.l: The hard stones shattered for his pain,

lem.l: Der sune let van groter dro&esup;fnisse ere schynent,

rdg.l: The sun stopped shining for great distress,

lem.l: De erde began van grotem yammer to beuen,

rdg.l: The earth began to quake for great sorrow,

lem.l: De doden in den grauen begunden ok wedder to leuen. -

rdg.l: The dead in the graves came back to life again.

lem.l: Leue vrunde, gy hebben hort, wat leden het Jhesus Cristus vnse

rdg.l: Dear friends, you have heard what our dear Lord Jesus Christ has suffered.

lem.l: Nu wyl ik juw lesen noch vuste mere:

rdg.l: Now I want to read much more to you:

lem.l: Dat lydent sunte Marien, dat wyl wij hijr nu anheuen.

rdg.l: We now want to start telling what St. Mary suffered.

lem.l: God late juw so lange leuen,

rdg.l: May God let you live so long

lem.l: Dat dij syne hulde vordenen, -

rdg.l: that you earn his grace,

lem.l: Vnde helpet huden sunte Marien wenen!

rdg.l: and, today, help to mourn St. Mary!

lem.l: Betrachtet huten myt vlyte ere byttercheyt,

rdg.l: Consider carefully today her bitterness

lem.l: De se so swarlyken leyt

rdg.l: that she suffered so deeply

lem.l: Vmme eres leuen kyndes dot,

rdg.l: for the death of her beloved child,

lem.l: Dar he vns mede geloset heft vth aller not!

rdg.l: by which he delivered us from all our misery!

lem.l: Hijr vmme, gij vrowen vnde ok gij man,

rdg.l: For that reason, all you women and men,

lem.l: Latet juw ere lydent to herten ga&esup;n!

rdg.l: let her suffering enter your heart!

lem.l: Bewenet dat van herten ynnichliken,

rdg.l: Lament this profoundly from the heart,

lem.l: Dat gij mogen myt vrowden ewychlyken

rdg.l: so that you can be joyfully and eternally

lem.l: Myt gode vnde myt Marien wesen

rdg.l: with God and with Mary

lem.l: Vnde vor der ewygen helle genesen!

rdg.l: and be saved from eternal Hell!

lem.l: Dat vns dat allen beschee,

rdg.l: For this, which is happening to all of us,

lem.l: So gat sytten vp juwe knee,

rdg.l: go down on your knees,

lem.l: Spreket eyn Pater noster myt ynnicheyt

rdg.l: say a heart-felt pater noster and an Ave Maria for the salvation of your soul!

lem.speaker: Johannes post Pater noster dicit ad omnem populum

rdg.speaker: Following the paternoster, John says to all of the people:

lem.l: Ghat sytten, gy leuen kynder, an dessen guden daghe,

rdg.l: Be seated, dear children on this fine day,

lem.l: Horet der reynen junckfrowen Marien weynent vnde klaghe!

rdg.l: hear the weeping and lament of the pure virgin Mary!

lem.speaker: Beata virgo Maria iucipit hic planctum suum dolorosissimum deuotissime. Psalmus:

rdg.speaker: St. Virgin Mary here piously begins her most sorrowful lamentation. Psalm:

lem.l: Anxiatus est in me spiritus meus,

rdg.l: My spirit is afraid,

lem.l: In me turbatum est cor meum!

rdg.l: My heart is restless!

lem.l: Nu bedrouet sik myn geyst an mynem herten sere,

rdg.l: Now the spirit in my heart becomes very sad,

lem.l: Noch mer wen gy wyf gewan dorch mynes kyndes ere.

rdg.l: exceeding even what you, women, gained through my child’s honor.

lem.speaker: Sancta Maria dicit et vertit se ad populum

rdg.speaker: St. Mary speaks and turns toward the audience.

lem.l: O aller barmhertigeste god,

rdg.l: Oh most merciful God,

lem.l: Wo grot ys myne klaghe vnde myn not

rdg.l: how great is my lament and my suffering

lem.l: Vmme Jhesus Cristum, den leuen sone myn!

rdg.l: because of Jesus Christ, my beloved son!

lem.l: Ik vruchte, he mot in groten noden syn.

rdg.l: I fear he may be in great peril.

lem.l: Ach woste yk, wor yk mochte

rdg.l: Alas, if I only knew where I could

lem.l: Ghan, dar yk ene sochte!

rdg.l: go to search for him!

lem.l: Dar gynge yk myt wyllen gerne hyn,

rdg.l: Gladly and willingly I’d go there

lem.l: Scholdet ok kosten dat leuent myn.

rdg.l: even if it would cost my life.

lem.speaker: Beata virgo cautat hoc

rdg.speaker: The blessed virgin sings this:

lem.l: Conturbata sunt omnia ossa mea, et anima mea turbata est valde.

rdg.l: All my bones are disquieted, and my soul is in great turmoil.

lem.speaker: Sancta Maria statim dicit ad Johannem:

rdg.speaker: St. Mary immediately says to John:

lem.l: Johannes, myn leue o&esup;m, wat mach dat beduden?

rdg.l: John, my dear nephew, what may that mean?

lem.l: Ghynnert synt gesammelt vele lude,

rdg.l: Many people have gathered,

lem.l: Se ropen lude und beren swar.

rdg.l: they are grieving loudly and behaving sadly.

lem.l: Eya nu gha myt my alda&esup;r

rdg.l: Come on, go there with me,

lem.l: La&esup;t vns beseen, wat see bedryuen!

rdg.l: let us have a look at what they are doing!

lem.speaker: Sanctus Johannes respondet

rdg.speaker: St. John responds:

lem.l: Neen, Maria leue medder wij moget leuer blyuen!

rdg.l: No, dear mother Mary, we would rather stay here!

lem.l: De yoden synt eres ouermodes also vil,

rdg.l: The Jews are so full of arrogance,

lem.l: Vor war ik dy dat saghen wyl.

rdg.l: in truth I want to tell you this!

lem.l: Se brochten sunte Peter darto in desser nacht,

rdg.l: They made St. Peter this night,

lem.l: Dat he synes heren vorso&esup;k vnde syner macht;

rdg.l: forsake his lord and his power;

lem.l: Schege my armen manne ok also,

rdg.l: if the same thing happened to me, a mere man,

lem.l: Des worde yk nummer vro.

rdg.l: I would never be happy again.

lem.speaker: Sancta Maria respondit

rdg.speaker: St. Mary responds:

lem.l: Johannes, myn vil leue vrund,

rdg.l: John, my very dear friend,

lem.l: Twyde my an desser stund,

rdg.l: listen to me at this hour

lem.l: Vnde ga myt my aldar,

rdg.l: and go with me there,

lem.l: Wente yd ys dar mennich var!

rdg.l: because there are many dangers!

lem.l: Lat vns beseen, wat se bedryuen!

rdg.l: Let us see what they are doing!

lem.l: Ik wyl stede by dy blyuen;

rdg.l: I will remain ever by your side;

lem.l: Myt der warheyt schaltu dat beseen:

rdg.l: in truth, you shall see this:

lem.l: Ik wyl vaste sta&esup;n vnde ok nicht van dy vleen

rdg.l: I will remain steadfast and not leave your side.

lem.l: Sume nicht! wij mogen nu nicht lenger stan.

rdg.l: Don’t delay! Let’s not stay here any longer.

lem.speaker: Sanctus Johannes respondet

rdg.speaker: St. John responds:

lem.l: Maria, leue medder, yk wyl gerne myt dy ga&esup;n.

rdg.l: Mary, dear mother, I will gladly go with you.

lem.l: Scholde yk ok darvmme lyn den bytteren dot,

rdg.l: Even if I suffer a bitter death,

lem.l: Ik vorlate dy nicht in desser groten not.

rdg.l: I will not abandon you in this great peril.

speaker.l: Valde modicum transeunt, silicet, si est opus, usque ad medium circuli.
Et sancta Maria statim incipit cantare

rdg.speaker: Quickly they move over, if necessary; namely, up into middle of the circle. And St. Mary immediately begins to sing:

lem.l: Owe des ghandes, des yk gha

rdg.l: Alas that I walk

lem.l: Myt yamer vnde myt ruwen!

rdg.l: With pain and sorrow!

lem.l: Myn kynt an deme crutze steyt,

rdg.l: My child is standing with the cross,

lem.l: Myn leyt wil sik vornuwen.

rdg.l: My suffering begins again.

lem.l: Owe, owy, owe

rdg.l: Alas, alas, alas

lem.l: Des gandes, des yk nu ghe!

rdg.l: That I must walk this path!

lem.l: Ik mot scrygen yummermer:

rdg.l: I must wail now and forever:
TRANSLATION OF SPOKEN LINE GOES HERE

lem.l: Owe, owy, owe!

rdg.l: Alas, alas, alas!

lem.l: Bedrouet synt de synne myn,

rdg.l: My senses are defeated,

lem.l: Went de heylant ys in pyn,

rdg.l: because the Saviour is in pain

lem.l: De myn kynt ys vnde ok myn god

rdg.l: who is my child and also my God,

lem.l: Vnde der enghel sabaoth.

rdg.l:
and the lord of angels.
According to Lexer, “sabaoth” means king of kings.

lem.l: Owy, owe!

rdg.l: Alas, alas!

lem.l: Owe, leyder wat ik nu vynde

rdg.l: Alas, more painful still is what I see

lem.l: An mynem herten truwen kynde!

rdg.l: in the child dear to my heart!

lem.l: Wor schal ik arme maget blyuen?

rdg.l: Where shall I, poor maiden remain?

lem.l: Dot, kum her vnde my vorswynde!

rdg.l: Death, come here and claim me!

lem.speaker: Sancta Maria extendit manum ad filium hic et dicit ad sanctum Johannes

rdg.speaker: Here St. Mary extends her hand to her son and says to St. John:

lem.l: See, Johannes leue o&esup;m,

rdg.l: See, John, dear nephew,

lem.l: Wat ys gehanget vor vns an den bo&esup;m,

rdg.l: what is hanging before us on the tree,

lem.l: Ys yd eyn mynsche edder eyn worm?

rdg.l: is it a man or a serpent?

lem.l: Id wyndet sik in den neghelen vnde drift groten storm;

rdg.l: It twists itself on the nails and is in the great throes of death;

lem.l: Id mot in groten bytteren pynen syn.

rdg.l: it must be in great and bitter pain.

lem.speaker: Sanctus Johannes respondet plangendo

rdg.speaker: St. John responds, mourning:

lem.l: Owe, Maria, dat ys dat leue kynt dyn!

rdg.l: Alas Mary, that is your beloved child!

lem.l: See, wo yd gevyllet sta&esup;t

rdg.l: See, how he hangs there tormented

lem.l: Vnde ok vp synem hilgen houede ha&esup;t

rdg.l: and around his holy head

lem.l: Van scharpen do&esup;rne eyne krone!

rdg.l: he has a crown of sharp thorns!

lem.l: Dat hilge blot vlut ouer syn antlat schone,

rdg.l: Holy blood flows over his lovely face

lem.l: Ok ouer syne ogen bet in syne munt.

rdg.l: Tand over his eyes and into his mouth.

lem.l: O Maria, see, wo yd steyt gewund:

rdg.l: O Mary, see how he hangs there tortured:

lem.l: Dat mochte eynem stene entfarmen!

rdg.l: that even a stone could be moved by it!

lem.l: O leuen kyndere, helpet dat altomale bekarmen!

rdg.l: O dear children, now all help to lament him!

lem.speaker: Sancta Maria respondet

rdg.speaker: Saint Mary responds:

lem.l: Owe, ys dat myn leue truten sone?

rdg.l: Alas, is that my dear beloved son?

lem.l: Ik wolde, dat syne scharpen dornekrone

rdg.l: I wish that his sharp crown of thorns

lem.l: Vp mynem houede sete an dessen stunden,

rdg.l: sat on my head in this hour,

lem.l: Vnde syne mennichualdigen depen wunden

rdg.l: and his many deep wounds

lem.l: Vor em weren an mynem lyue,

rdg.l: were on my body

lem.l: Vppe dat he mochte leuendich blyuen.

rdg.l: instead of his so that he could stay alive.

lem.p: Et cantat:

rdg.p: And she sings:

lem.l: Owe, yamer vnde not!

rdg.l: Alas, pain and misery!

lem.l: Owe, mynes leuen kyndes dot,

rdg.l: Alas, the death of my dear child

lem.l: Den ik an herten drage

rdg.l: that I carry in my heart

lem.l: Vnde so yamerliken klaghe!

rdg.l: and lament so sorrowfully!

lem.l: Yo gha ik wedder vnde dort,

rdg.l: Now I go here and there,

lem.l: Noch entret hijr nemant vort,

rdg.l: and still no one here steps forward

lem.l: De desse martere beweynede!

rdg.l: to mourn this suffering!

lem.l: Owe, elende!

rdg.l: Alas, miserable ones!

lem.l: Owy, owe my huten vnde jummermer

rdg.l: Alas, woe is me today and forevermore

lem.l: Vmme mynes kyndes do&esup;t!

rdg.l: because of my child’s death!

lem.l: Myn kummer ys so rechte grot.

rdg.l: My sorrow is so very great.

lem.l: Owy, owe!

rdg.l: Alas, woe is me!

lem.p: Et dicit vlterius

rdg.p: And continues:

lem.l: Eya, moderlyke herte,

rdg.l: Oh, motherly heart,

lem.l: Wat lydestu pyne vnde smerte!

rdg.l: how you are suffering misery and pain!

lem.speaker: Dominus Jhesus dicit habens crucifixum ante se

rdg.speaker: Holding the cross in front of him, Lord Jesus says:

lem.l: Myn volk, wo seer hestu dy an my gewraken!

rdg.l: My people, how much you have tormented me!

lem.l: Ik hebbe dy doch nicht to leyde gedan edder gespraken?

rdg.l: I didn’t do or say anything to harm you.

lem.l: Myn volk, yk vorede dy ouer dat wylde meer

rdg.l: My people, I lead you over the wild sea

lem.l: Vnde vordruckede Pharaonis heer;

rdg.l: and I swallowed Faroah’s army;

lem.l: Ik reghende dy enghelsch brod

rdg.l: I made the angels’ bread rain down

lem.l: Yn der wo&esup;stenyge to dyner no&esup;t:

rdg.l: in the desert to relieve your hardship:

lem.l: Darvmme hestu my ghevanghen

rdg.l: this is why you captured me

lem.l: Vnde darto an dat crutze gehanghen!

rdg.l: and hung me on the cross!

lem.l: De vosse hebben ere kulen,

rdg.l: Foxes have their dens

lem.l: Dar se ynne schulen,

rdg.l: where they hide,

lem.l: De vogele hebben ere neste,

rdg.l: birds have their nests,

lem.l: De heren hebben ere gheveste, -

rdg.l: lords have their strongholds,

lem.l: Des mynschen sone leyder nicht enha&esup;t,

rdg.l: -- the son of man sadly doesn’t have any place

lem.l: Dar syn kranke houet ane sta&esup;t.

rdg.l: where his poor head may rest.

lem.l: Owy vnde we, wart doch ny mynschen so we!

rdg.l: Alas and alas, never did anyone suffer so much!

lem.speaker: Sancta Maria cantat post hoc

rdg.speaker: Then St. Mary sings:

lem.l: Ik horede enen ro&esup;p:

rdg.l: I heard a cry:

lem.l: Dat ys mynt kynt Jhesus, de myr geschop

rdg.l: that is my child Jesus, who created me

lem.l: Vnde al de werlt gemeyne;

rdg.l: and all the world together;

lem.l: Des mot yk arme schrygen vnde weynen.

rdg.l: because of that I must weep and cry.

lem.l: Van Jherusalem gy vrowen,

rdg.l: You women of Jerusalem,

lem.l: Nu helpet huden schowen

rdg.l: now join me in watching

lem.l: Mynes leuen kyndes dot,

rdg.l: the death of my beloved child,

lem.l: Dat hyr hanget naket vnde blot!

rdg.l: who hangs here naked and stripped.

lem.l: Owy, owe!

rdg.l: Alas, alas!

lem.speaker: Sancta Maria dicit post hoc ricmum

rdg.speaker: After these rhymes, St. Mary says:

lem.l: Ach wo grote pyne vnde smerte

rdg.l: Oh, what great pain and sorrow

lem.l: Lydet myn arm bedrouede herte

rdg.l: my poor afflicted heart suffers

lem.l: Vmme mynes leuen kyndes byttercheyt,

rdg.l: Because of the torment of my dear child,

lem.l: Dat in so groter not an deme hilgen crutze steyt!

rdg.l: who hangs on the holt cross in such great misery!

lem.l: Weren vnse herte ok van steynen,

rdg.l: Even if our hearts were of stone,

lem.l: Se mosten doch nu mede weynen.

rdg.l: Tthey would still have to weep with us.

lem.speaker: Sancta Maria vertit se ad filias Jerusalem dicens vel cantans

rdg.speaker: St. Mary turns to the daughters of Jerusalem, saying, or rather singing:

lem.l: Weynet gij truwen susteren myn,

rdg.l: Weep you loyal sisters of mine,

lem.l: Helpet my armen drouych syn

rdg.l: join me in my sadness

lem.l: Vnde klagen mynen not!

rdg.l: and lament my misery!

lem.l: Myn kummer ys worden grot

rdg.l: My grief has grown and grown

lem.l: Vmme mynes kyndes do&esup;t.

rdg.l: at the death of my child.

lem.p: Et dicit vltra ad filias Jherusalem

rdg.p: And she says, continuing, to the daughters of Jerusalem:

lem.l: Gij leuen sustere, latet juw entbarmen

rdg.l: You dear sisters,

lem.l: Huden ouer my vyl armen!

rdg.l: have pity today for poor me!

lem.l: Seet an myne smerte vnde grote byttercheyt,

rdg.l: Look at my pain and my great torment,

lem.l: De yk an mynem herten drage vmme mynes kyndes leyt!

rdg.l: that I carry in my heart because of my child’s suffering!

lem.speaker: Sancta Maria Magdalena

rdg.speaker: St. Mary Magdalene:

lem.l: O quantus luctus

rdg.l: Oh, what great grief

lem.l: Nobis est inductus

rdg.l: is laid upon us

lem.l: Pre hac tristicia!

rdg.l: by this sadness!

lem.l: Owe vns armen!

rdg.l: Alas, poor us!

lem.l: Got late sik irbarmen

rdg.l: God have mercy

lem.l: Ouer vnse grote leyt!

rdg.l: on our suffering!

lem.speaker: Sancta Maria Magdalena vadit ad medium et dicit ricmum

rdg.speaker: St. Mary Magdalene goes to the center and says in rhyme:

lem.l: Owe, wo grote yamercheyt

rdg.l: Alas, how great sorrow

lem.l: Vns armen vrowen nu besteyt

rdg.l: affects us poor women now

lem.l: Dorch de bytteren martere vnses leuen heren,

rdg.l: because of the bitter martyrdom of our dear Lord,

lem.l: Den huten de yoden myt groten vneren

rdg.l: whom today the Jews, with great dishonor,

lem.l: Vnde myt vnschult hebben to deme dode bracht!

rdg.l: put to death, an innocent man!

lem.l: Eya, dyt ys wol eyn bedrouet dach,

rdg.l: Oh, this is indeed a sorrowful day,

lem.l: Dat wij ene vor vns hanghen seen!

rdg.l: on which we see him hanging before us!

lem.l: Wo mochte vns groter leyt bescheen!

rdg.l: How could any greater sorrow befall us!

lem.l: O leue here Jhesu Criste, wo gherne stoure yk vmme dy,

rdg.l: O, beloved lord Jesus Christ, how gladly I would die in your place,

lem.l: Wente van groten sunden hestu gheloset my.

rdg.l: because you have delivered me from great sins.

lem.p: Et cantat vlterius pro gratiarum actione

rdg.p: And she continues in song, as an act of gratitude:

lem.l: Ghelauet systu, here Jhesu Crist,

rdg.l: Praise be unto you, lord Jesus Christ

lem.l: Went du also barmehertich byst,

rdg.l: because you are so merciful,

lem.l: Dattu dy yo wult irbarmen

rdg.l: that you show mercy

lem.l: Ouer my vyl armen!

rdg.l: to poor me!

lem.l: Du hest geloset my,

rdg.l: you have saved me;

lem.l: Des wyl yk jummer lauen dy.

rdg.l: for that I will always praise you.

lem.speaker: Maria Magdalena dicit statim ad beatam virginem

rdg.speaker: Mary Magdalene immediately says to the Blessed Virgin:

lem.l: O Maria, eddele, reyne maghet,

rdg.l: Oh Mary, noble and pure maiden,

lem.l: Dyn grote lydent sij deme leuen gode gheklaghet.

rdg.l: your great suffering shall be mourned before God.

lem.speaker: Mater Johannis ewangeliste cantat post hoc

rdg.speaker: Then the mother of John the Evangelist sings:

lem.l: Jam auctor lucis

rdg.l: TNow the creator of light

lem.l: Nunc in ligno crucis

rdg.l: hangs constrained

lem.l: Stat in angustia.

rdg.l: on the wood of a cross.

lem.l: Nu sy wij myt sorgen

rdg.l: Now, today, we are

lem.l: Huten gar vorborgen

rdg.l: laden with troubles

lem.l: Vnde in der yamercheyt.

rdg.l: and in sorrow.

lem.speaker: Mater Johannis dicit

rdg.speaker: The mother of John says:

lem.l: O wo grote not vnde smerte

rdg.l: Oh what great misery and pain

lem.l: Lyden nu vnse bedroueden herte,

rdg.l: our saddened hearts suffer now

lem.l: Wente wij Jhesum Cristum, der waren sunnen schyn,

rdg.l: because we see Jesus Christ, the true light of the sun,

lem.l: In groter yamercheyt vor vns hangen seen!

rdg.l: hanging in front of us in great sorrow!

lem.l: O leuen kyndere, bewenet nu vnses heren dot,

rdg.l: Oh dear children, now weep for our lord’s death

lem.l: Vppe dat he vns mote losen vth aller no&esup;t!

rdg.l: so that he might deliver us from all hardship!

lem.l: O leue here Jhesu Criste, mochte yk nu myt dy steruen

rdg.l: O dear lord Jesus Christ, if I could die with you now,

lem.l: Vnde also dyne hulde vorweruen,

rdg.l: and with that procure your grace,

lem.l: Ik sumede nicht bet tho morghen

rdg.l: I would not wait until tomorrow

lem.l: Vnde wolde dar ok nicht vore sorghen.

rdg.l: and also would not think twice about it.

lem.l: Maria, leue suster, dyn grote lydent vnde weynen

rdg.l: Mary, dear sister, your great suffering and weeping

lem.l: Mochte vntfarmen deme harden steyne.

rdg.l: would move a hard stone to pity.

lem.speaker: Sancta Maria vertit se ad populum et dicit

rdg.speaker: St. Mary turns to the audience and says:

lem.l: Ach wo grote pyne vnde smerte

rdg.l: Oh, what great pain and sorrow

lem.l: Lydet myn arme bedrouede herte

rdg.l: my poor afflicted heart suffers

lem.l: Vmme mynes leuen kyndes byttercheyt,

rdg.l: Because of the torment of my dear child,

lem.l: De in so groter not an deme hilgen crutze steyt!

rdg.l: ho hangs on the holy cross in such great misery!

lem.l: Weren vnse herte ok van steynen,

rdg.l: Even if our hearts were of stone,

lem.l: See mosten doch nu mede weynen.

rdg.l: they would still have to weep with us.

lem.speaker: Maria cantat

rdg.speaker: Mary sings:

lem.l: Vrunt Johannes, neue gute,

rdg.l: Friend John, dear nephew,

lem.l: Help my armen godes moter

rdg.l: help me, poor mother of God

lem.l: Klagen mynes kyndes leuent,

rdg.l: to lament the life of my child

lem.l: Dat deme dode ys gegeuen!

rdg.l: who has been put to death!

lem.l: O wat Cristus duldet

rdg.l: Oh what Christ suffers,

lem.l: Vnde an deme crutze sweuet

rdg.l: hanging on the cross,

lem.l: Gar al vnuorschuldt!

rdg.l: free of guilt!

lem.speaker: Sancta Maria ad filium suum benedictum dicit hoc et ad sanctum Johannem ewangelistam

rdg.speaker: St. Mary says this to her blessed son and to St. John the Evangelist:

lem.l: O wy vnde we, wo grot herteleyt

rdg.l: Oh, alas and alack, what great heartache

lem.l: Ys my armen bedroueden moder nu bereyt,

rdg.l: now afflicts me, a poor wretched mother,

lem.l: O leue kynt, vmme de bytteren marter dyn!

rdg.l: O dear child, because of your bitter torment!

lem.l: Hijr vmme, Johannes, leue neue myn,

rdg.l: Therefore John, my dear nephew,

lem.l: Help my armen moder beklagen vnde beweynen

rdg.l: help this poor mother to lament and bewail

lem.l: Jhesum Cristum den vyl reynen,

rdg.l: Jesus Christ, in his purity

lem.l: Den de yoden hebben gevanghen

rdg.l: whom the Jews took captive

lem.l: Vnde ok an dat hilge crutze ghehangen!

rdg.l: and hanged on that holy cross!

lem.l: Leue o&esup;m, lat dy dit to herten ga&esup;n,

rdg.l: Dear nephew, let this enter your heart,

lem.l: Wente he dy alle gud heft geda&esup;n!

rdg.l: Tbecause he has only done good things for you!

lem.speaker: Sanctus Johannes cantat et vertit se ad populum

rdg.speaker: Saint John sings and turns to the people:

lem.l: Tristor et cuncti tristantur

rdg.l: I am saddened and all are saddened

lem.l: De tua tristicia;

rdg.l: because of your misery;

lem.l: [Omnes] Tecum lacrimantur,

rdg.l: all are crying with you,

lem.l: Eructant suspiria.

rdg.l: they are breaking out in loud sighs.

lem.l: Hic rubescit oculus,

rdg.l: These eyes are becoming red,

lem.l: Flet fidelis populus

rdg.l: the faithful people cry

lem.l: De Cristi mesticia.

rdg.l: over Christ’s torments.

lem.l: Maria, moder vnde maget reyne,

rdg.l: Mary, mother and pure virgin,

lem.l: Yk byn dyner suster kynt.

rdg.l: I am your sister’s child.

lem.l: Dyn grote scrygent vnde dyn weynent

rdg.l: Your great crying and wailing

lem.l: Klagen alle, de hijr synt.

rdg.l: *is lamented by all who are present.

lem.l: Hijr wert vyl mennich oge rot

rdg.l: Here many eyes are turning red

lem.l: Vmme dynes kyndes dot,

rdg.l: because of the death of your child

lem.l: Dat hijr hanget ver vns blot.

rdg.l: who hangs here in front of us naked.

lem.speaker: Johannes vltra dicit ad Mariam, matrem Cristi

rdg.speaker: John then says to Mary, mother of Christ:

lem.l: Maria, leue medder, he scholde eyn steynen herte dragen,

rdg.l: Mary, dear mother, he would have to have a heart of stone,

lem.l: De dynes kyndes dot nicht kunde helpen beklagen;

rdg.l: who could refrain from helping lament the death of your child.

lem.l: Wart gy mynsche so steynen,

rdg.l: Are you people made of stone

lem.l: De nu myt vns nicht kunde weynen?

rdg.l: that you cannot cry with us?

lem.l: Maria, leue medder, we nu wyl rechte ouerdencken

rdg.l: Mary, dear mother, the one who will now rightly consider

lem.l: Vnde ok in syn herte sencken

rdg.l: and take into his heart your crying,

lem.l: Dyn weynent, den scrygent, dynes reynen herten not

rdg.l: Tyour wailing, the grief of your pure heart

lem.l: Vnde dynes leuen kyndes bytter dot,

rdg.l: and the bitter death of your dead child,

lem.l: De mot myt dy trurent han

rdg.l: can share your sorrow

lem.l: Vnde aller werlde valsche vrowde la&esup;n.

rdg.l: and relinquish the false joy of all the world.

lem.speaker: Sancta Maria Magdalena et mater Johannis ewangeliste simul cantat

rdg.speaker: St. Mary Magdalene and the mother of John the Evangelist sing together:

lem.l: O quam tristis et afflicta

rdg.l: Oh, how sad and afflicted

lem.l: Fuit illa benedicta

rdg.l: was the blessed

lem.l: Mater vnigeniti!

rdg.l: mother of the incarnated!

lem.l: Quis est homo, qui non fleret,

rdg.l: Who is the man who does not cry,

lem.l: Matrem Cristi si videret

rdg.l: when he sees the mother of Christ

lem.l: In tanto supplicio?

rdg.l: in such great anguish?

lem.speaker: Mater Johannis dicit ricmum

rdg.speaker: The mother of John says in rhyme:

lem.l: Ach, ach, wo sere lyde wy grote swere

rdg.l: Alas, alas, how greatly we bear an immense burden

lem.l: Vmme dy, o leue truten here!

rdg.l: for your sake, oh dear beloved lord!

lem.speaker: Sancta Maria cantat et vertit se ad occidentem

rdg.speaker: St. Mary sings and turns to the west:

lem.l: We helpet klagen myn grote leyt?

rdg.l: Who will help lament my great pain?

lem.l: Myn yamer de ys worden breyt.

rdg.l: My sorrow has become immense.

lem.l: Wo kan ik arme dat nu dragen,

rdg.l: How can I, poor me, now bear that

lem.l: Went yk in alle mynen dagen

rdg.l: when, in all of my days,

lem.l: Ny vornam sulke swere!

rdg.l: I have never experienced such a burden!

lem.l: Horen noch seen yk enkan;

rdg.l: I can neither hear nor see:

lem.l: So grot leyt ny wyf gewan,

rdg.l: such great suffering no woman has ever endured

lem.l: So yk arme nu dulde,

rdg.l: as I - poor me - now do,

lem.l: Went he steruet ane schulde;

rdg.l: since he dies without guilt:

lem.l: Dat komet van syner lere.

rdg.l: that results from his teaching.

lem.speaker: Hic Maria virgo inspicit filium et eleuat manus ita cantans:

rdg.speaker: Here the Virgin Mary looks at her son and raises her hands, singing thus:

lem.l: Trut sone myn,

rdg.l: My beloved son,

lem.l: De moder dyn

rdg.l: your mother

lem.l: An desser stunt

rdg.l: at this hour

lem.l: Vt herten grunt

rdg.l: from the bottom of her heart

lem.l: Dy byddet ynnichliken:

rdg.l: prays fervently:

lem.l: Giff my dynen dot

rdg.l: Grant me death

lem.l: In desser not!

rdg.l: in my peril!

lem.l: Myn herte, brich,

rdg.l: Break my heart,

lem.l: Went ik see dich

rdg.l: for I see you

lem.l: Hangen so yamerlyken!

rdg.l: hanging so wretchedly!

lem.l: Hertenkynt, sprych,

rdg.l: Child of my heart, speak,

lem.l: Myn not ys so bytterlich!

rdg.l: my sorrow is so bitter!

lem.speaker: Hic Johannes capit gladium ambabus manibus, cum eo tangens virginis pectus genebus flexis. Et Maria cantat vlterius

rdg.speaker: Here John grasps the sword with both hands and with it touches the chest of the kneeling Virgin. Mary continues, singing:

lem.l: Trut sone wert,

rdg.l: Beloved worthy son,

lem.l: My geyt eyn swert

rdg.l: a sword of misery

lem.l: Van yamer dorch myn herte!

rdg.l: pierces my heart!

lem.l: Do vp dyne ogen, see my an,

rdg.l: Raise your eyes, look at me,

lem.l: Lose myner sorgen bant!

rdg.l: release the binds of my suffering!

lem.l: Trut sone, kynt,

rdg.l: Beloved son, child,

lem.l: Blodich dyne lede synt,

rdg.l: your limbs are bloody,

lem.l: Dat gift my grote smerte!

rdg.l: that causes me great pain.

lem.l: Brich, herte myn, brich,

rdg.l: Break my heart, break,

lem.l: Went yk hijr sta so bytterlich!

rdg.l: since I stand her so wretchedly!

lem.l: So enmach nemant trosten mych,

rdg.l: Nothing may console me

lem.l: Men de dot alleyne.

rdg.l: but death alone

lem.l: Ik bydde dy, dot,

rdg.l: I beg you, death,

lem.l: Kum, lose my vth desser not!

rdg.l: come, release me from this grief!

lem.l: My ys worden myn herte dot,

rdg.l: My heart has died,

lem.l: Ik enmach nicht mer weynen.

rdg.l: I cannot cry anymore.

lem.l: Eya valsche yodenkynt,

rdg.l: Alas, duplicitous Jew-children,

lem.l: Wo synt gy myt synnen blynt,

rdg.l: How could you be so senseless

lem.l: Dat gy myn trut leue kynt

rdg.l: as to destroy my dear beloved,

lem.l: Aldus ane schult vorderuen!

rdg.l: innocent child thus!

lem.l: Wat han ik arme ju gedan,

rdg.l: What have I, so wretched, done to you,

lem.l: Dat gy myn leuent lan

rdg.l: that you let my life continue

lem.l: In so groter swere stan?

rdg.l: in such great misery?

lem.l: Yk wunsche myt em to steruen.

rdg.l: I wish to die with him.

lem.p: Hic Maria Magdalena et mater Johannis cantant secundo simul sicut prius canticum "O quam tristis et afflicta" s. et mater Johannis dicit ricmum "Ach ach, wo sere" vt prius.

rdg.p: Here Mary Magdalene and the mother of John sing together for the second time the earlier song “How sad and afflicted”. The mother of John says the rhyme “Alas, alas how greatly”

lem.p: Post hoc statim beata virgo Maria, si potest hoc commodose fieri.

rdg.p: Immediately after this, the Blessed Virgin Mary, if it can be done conveniently,

lem.p: incipit secundo cum omni deuocione canticum "We helpet klagen myn grot leyt? Myn yamer de ys worden breyt" vt prius.

rdg.p: begins for the second time with great devotion “Who will help to lament my great pain? My sorrow has become so immense" as before

lem.p: Et cantat ex integro cum omnibus gestibus sicut prius.

rdg.p: And she sings with all her heart with all the gestures just as before.

lem.speaker: Sancta Maria quando finiat canticum istud secundo dicit ricmum

rdg.speaker: When Saint Mary finishes this song for the second time, she says this rhyme:

lem.l: Eya schone bouen alle schone

rdg.l: Alas, beauty above all beauty,

lem.l: Eya herteleue sone,

rdg.l: alas, son, dear to my heart,

lem.l: Wor ys dyne schone hengevaren?

rdg.l: where has your beauty disappeared to?

lem.l: Du werest de allerschoneste gebaren,

rdg.l: You were the most beautiful child

lem.l: De gy van moderlyue gebaren wart,

rdg.l: ever born of a mother's womb,

lem.l: Also wunnychlyck vnde tzart!

rdg.l: so delightful and tender!

lem.l: Dy weren dyne wanghen,

rdg.l: Your cheeks were

lem.l: Oft se myt rosen weren behanghen;

rdg.l: as if they were garlanded with roses,

lem.l: Dyn antlat scheen also de sunne,

rdg.l: your face shone like the sun,

lem.l: Dyn ogenblyk was also eyn vrolyk wunne.

rdg.l: your gaze was joyful bliss.

lem.l: O leue sone Jhesu Crist,

rdg.l: Oh, beloved son Jesus Christ,

lem.l: Wo sere du nu gewundet byst!

rdg.l: how terribly you are wounded now!

lem.l: Dy synt dyne lede van blode rot,

rdg.l: Your limbs are red with blood

lem.l: Wentu an deme crutze lydest grote not.

rdg.l: since you are suffering great anguish on the cross.

lem.l: Eya, du valsche yoden deyt,

rdg.l: Oh you false deed of the Jews,

lem.l: Du werest dar sere to bereyt

rdg.l: which was well built

lem.l: Dattu myn leue kynt mochtest bevlecken!

rdg.l: to stain my beloved child!

lem.l: Ik wyl dat wedder bedecken:

rdg.l: I want to cover him again:

lem.l: Id schal nicht lengher naket stan,

rdg.l: He shall not remain naked any longer,

lem.l: Mynen do&esup;k wyl yk em vmme sla&esup;n,

rdg.l: and I, poor mother Mary, will borrow another shawl later.

lem.l: Wente yk arme moder Marie

rdg.l: TRANSLATION OF SPOKEN LINE GOES HERE

lem.l: Eynen anderen doek wedder lye.

rdg.l: TRANSLATION OF SPOKEN LINE GOES HERE

lem.p: Sancta Maria accipit hic pannum de serico album, cum quo tegit lumbos crucifixi, quem iuuenis quidam tenet cum galdio Symeonis et statim subdit.

rdg.p: TRANSLATION OF STAGE DIRECTION GOES HERE
